column4: im creating a backup script to rsync from one machine to another across the net, trouble is I can't backup because even though both have ssh open they block ROOT and i really want to rsync a copy of the entire machine....any thoughts
have you attempted starting rsync with sudo
how do you mean? since starting "sudo rsync -avz user@hostname:/ /backupmachine" would result in not logging in as root permissions
remember root is blocked on both sides
you do not need to log into the remote machine as root to backup everything from the source
the destination of your backup will not need root, since you can store the entire contents in a non protected dir, you only need to start rsync with sudo, and log into the SSH server as a normal user
but that user who i login as can't read some of the files that dont allow other then root into certain directories?
im confused, you are just backing up the entire source (say, server A) and putting it in a dir on destincation (say, server B) correct?
if that is the case, then only root access is needed on server A to read the files. Since you can place them anywhere on server B, you do not need root access on server B
is there a way without opening root access?
if you need to backup EVERYTHING, root access is needed on server A
like is it possible to allow a user to be root like without sudo
just use sudo, i dont reccomend allowing a user root access without having to use sudo
i understand the risks i was hoping to allow ssh only by ip or something that would actually prevent anyone from trying root attempts
look into allowing SSH access with SSL certs
but for your original question, just start rsync with sudo, and log into server B as normal user. good luck, i gotta get to work ^_^
